Coeds banned retroactively
Voting after a long and heated
session yesterday, the Committee
on Undergraduate Studies
retroactively eliminated
coeducation from the
Homewood campus.
The vote, which was
unanimous, means that all
women undergraduates will be
forced to leave Hopkins and that
all women who have received
degrees and academic credit from
the University since coeducation
was instituted in September,
1970, will have those credentials
withdrawn.
Although the CUS has no
powers to do so itself, the panel
also recommended to Director of
Plant and Planning Operations
William L. Campbell that the
mural, "The Beauties of
Baltimore" in the lobby of
Shriver Hall be covered over with
an idyllic country scene. "We
want the guys to think about
their work, not about what

they're going to do Friday
night," commented Dean of
Academic Programs, Sigmund
Suskind.
Explaining his reasons for
asking the CUS to ban
coeducation retroactively,
Suskind said last night, "I think
women belong in the kitcfien
baking cookies, not in the
laboratory plaguing microbes."
Suskind further stated that all
women undergraduates are to be
off the Homewood campus by
noon today. "Any former female
undergraduate I see walking this
campus this afternoon will be
arrested by Baltimore city police
and charged with trespassing,"
Suskind pledged.
He also stated that his office
had been receiving "substantial
heat" from graduate and
professional schools concerning
the status of coeducation here.
"Some med schools feel that the
quality .of undergraduate

education is severely affected by
the presence of women. You
know, guys can't think about
their work with all that ass
around."

Gazette to fold after 27 months
By MAX NEMSER
The Gazette, the official news
organ of the Hopkins
administration, will suspend
publication indefinitely this week
because of a loss of readership,
according to Bob Hewes,
Director of Public Information.
The Gazette, established in
September of 1971. was the
official newspaper of record for
all divisions of the University.
The purpose of the Gazette was
to improve communication
within and among all divisions of
the University, according to a
September, 1972, edition of the
paper. In its heyday, the Gazette
was printing more than ten
thousand copies weekly and was
distributed to students, faculty
and employees.

Former Editor Robert Hewes
prepares for Christmas.

"Within the last year, our
readership has dwindled from
around 6,000 readers to barely
more than 32," said Hewes.
"And those 32 people are' all
located in Garland Hall," he
added.
According to Hewes,
competition from the
News-Letter the student run
publication, had nothing to do
with the termination of the
Gazette.

"I don't think that the
News-Letter had anything to do
with this [the suspension of
publication]," said Hewes. "I
believe what we see here is a
trend away from reading," he
added.
Hewes predicts an increase in
the number of people attending
the various film series on campus
along with decreases in the

Hopkins to merge
with Naval Academy
As a recording of "Anchors
Aweigh" was playing in the
background, President Muller
announced last night that
Hopkins will merge with the U.S.
Naval Academy, effective July 1,
1974.
The merger, which represents
Hopkins' second attempt this
year to find a school to unite
with, means that all Homewood
students will become officers in
the U.S. Navy or the Marine
Corps on graduation. In order to
meet requirements for

Rats overrun Homewood Campus
Last Saturday night, Ames and
Mergenthaler Halls were scenes of
a massive take-over by the rat
populations of both buildings as
cage-doors were apparently jarred
open by an explosion on the
construction site of the new
Student Union.
Director of Campus Security,
George Weinbach, labelled the
incident "freaky" and related the
subsequent uprising by the
rodents to a similar incident
which occurred "in -that rodent
feature of all times,'Willard."
"This is obviously been in the
works for quite some time,"
commented Weinbach on the rat
coup. "I would imagine that
these little fellows were waiting
just for the right diversion to put
their plan into action."
The explosion at the Student
Union which set the cages open
has been attributed to gorilla

warfare, according to Campus
Security. Patrolmen stated that
damage to the Union was limited
to the RATskeller area.
"This is going to call for some
drastic action," continued
Weinbach. "I've called in two
thousand cats to help control the
numbers of these little, dirty
rats."
Weinbach estimated that over
four thousand rats were on the
loose and were taking part in
discrete, subversive activities on
campus.
"We've had reports of large
raids on the lard of the Saga
Food Company in the Old Dorms
and in the Levering Hall
Kitchen," Weinbach commented.
"They've completely taken over
the underground tunnels on
campus and I suspect their next
raid will be in the vicinity of the
Psychology Building as they

required to spend two summers
training with naval and marine
corps units.
Muller, who spent two years in
the U.S. Army Signal Corps, said
of the merger move,"I think this
will mean great things for the
future of the University. We will
become an arm of the U.S.
government and an integral part
of the military-industrial
complex, a goal._ toward which
this university has long been
striving."
Under provisions of the plan,
announced by Muller as he stood
on the deck of the Ridgely
Warfield, the University's only
nautical asset, all Hopkins
students will be required to
spend two of their four years
here in residence at the Naval
Academy in Annapolis.
Midshipmen live a spartan
schedule there, rising at 6 a.m.
and usually not getting to bed
again before midnight.
In order to remain enrolled at
Hopkins, students will have to
pass the Naval facility's rigorous
physical examination, which
requires that examinees have at
least 20/40 vision, be able to run
the 100-yard dash in 10 seconds
or less and drink six -cans. of
National Boh without going to
the bathroom.
Student Council president
Andrew W. Savitz said of the
merger plan, "Oh, my God." He
then commented, "Well, I'm
transferring to Harvard anyway
so it doesn't matter to me."
Secretary of Defense James R.
Schlesinger was unavailable for
comment on the merger matter.

New lecture series
to meet at midnight
By CREIGHTON BLACK
"Out of the old grows the
new" prophesied University
Chaplain, Chester L. Wickwire,
and with these words the new
campus lecture series, The
Sundesday Noon Experience was
commenced.
The new series is a merger of
two eliminated campus lecture
series; Wednesday Noon and the
Sunday Experience.
The sponsors of S.N.E. are
pleased with the new
arrangement citing competition
as the major cause of the union.
Duplication was also a
,contributing factor.
The new series which will meet
in the Greenhouse behind Gilman
every Tuesday night at midnight
will follow a similar free format
but will be even more bizarre in
speaker selection.
The first lecturer will be
Salvatore "Sonny" Battaglia,
owner-operator of the legendary
B&M Sandwich Shop at the
corner of 31st and Guilford. Dr.
Battaglia (honorary doctorate in
food preparation from the Julia
Child School of Eats) will be
delivering an address entitled
"Everything You Wanted to
Know About Food But Were
Afraid to Ask".
Renowned for his culinary
delights and ambrosia, Dr.
Battaglia is also a highly regarded
expert on the subject of interior
design. It is his work, "Grape

the grass.

probably think Nixon is clean
of all these Watergate charges."
There was one member of the
City Council, however, that saw
some redeeming value in a
Fitzpatrick senate campaign.

has gotten so liberal I think
we're due for some reshufflin'.

see a good middle of the road
member of my party back in
the Senate. The last one I
remember was Tydings'
grandfather. Just like Saul of
Tarsus, I think Bob Fitzpatrick
can see the light."

supporter for Senator George

Be Zarre promises fun and frolicking fun for all
Be Zarre, a new sport devised
for Hopkins Undergraduates, will
commence with the January
Intersession training period,
Director of Athletics Bob Scott
announced yesterday.
According to Scott, the sport
will consist of riding horses
through Gilman Quad and
attempting to trample as many
people as possible within the
fifteen minutes of each quarter.
Practice dummies will be in place
during the winter, with the
regular season highlighted by
"3400 On Stage" during April
and "Commencement" late in
May.
"Personally, I think that this is
the greatest sport ever to hit the
Homewood Campus," said
Marshall Turner, who will be
coaching the squad. "It allows

the participants to relieve their
frustrations from the work day as
well as Novide the Infirmary
personnel with some real work to
perform."
Turner Sez
According to other sources,
the sport will commence as soon
as enough students express
interest in the event.

"We'd like to see the entire
campus join in the fun," said
Turner, suggesting that those
who don't ride may be used as
dummies.
"Oh boy, I just can't wait,"
said Trainer LeRoy Brandimore
gleefully. "Be Zarre is bound to
create a demand for my services
and should insure my job for

NEWS-1E11'ER

years to come."
A special exhibition of the
new sport will be held this week,
according to Turner, when all
professors giving exams will be
lined up between Remsen and
Ames Halls. "If nothing else
attracts interest to this great
game, I am certain this stunt
can't fail," Turner explained.

Jays cop NCAA white-water title

Pierre Marquette concentrates on Coxswain Lydia
LaTush while
winning the White Water Crown.

The Blue Jay canoeists
paddled to their first NCAA title
ever Saturday afternoon, winning
the White Water championships
in the final day of competition.
Hopkins outstroked the
contingent from Grand Canyon
College of the Big Fish to seal the
win.
Never before had so
many canoespopulated Wyman
Park Creek, site of the First
Annual Title Tilt. Boaters from
63 schools, including
powerhouses such as Missoula
State, Red River University, and
Lewis and Clark Teaching
College, took part in the
competition.
Hiawatha Gitigumee, an
advisor from the Board of Indian
Affairs, was on hand to offer the
NCAA technical expertise in the
proper manner to run the affair.
The BIA representative officiated
over the solemn moments at the
beginning and end of the meet.
Led by captain Pierre
Marquette, the Blue Jay dugouts
finished one, three, and twelve in

the 1000 yard finale. Marquette's
skillful feathering and the
encouraging strains from his
coxswain, Lydia Latush, inspired
the rest of the Hopkins squad
and produced the victory.
Not Booters
Hopkins boaters (not booters)
also dominated the 500 and 2500
yard events. Sprinter Jerk
McGurk who hails from Moose's
Jaw Saskatchewan, and distance

specialist Lif Erikson, a junior
from Godthaab, .Greenland
joined Marquette on the
All-American squad.
"Homestream advantage had
nothing to do with our smashing
victory," said Marquette,
claimimg it was merely a
coincidence that the only
navigate the course without
striking the roving granite
obstacles were Blue.

Jackson says lax is for sissies
Lacrosse just ain't the game it
used to be," decried former
Hopkins stick star Seymour
'Action" Jackson. "As soon as
they required helmets and
illowed all that other wimpish
protective equipment the sport
lost its quality as a test of
manhood."
The thirty-nine year old
midfielder has just been named
on of the assistant coaches for
the 1974 Blue Jay squad. After
losing two successive NCAA
crowns by a single goal in the
championship game, Head Coach
Bob Scott believes some new
tactical approach is needed.
Feared throughout the nation
during his playing days, Jackson
still holds the USILA record for
penalty minutes. Known as "The
Scalper", he had a proclivity for

On The Head calls and served
100 minutes in the penalty box
and fourteen years at San
Quentin.
Just how he would help the
Blue Jays remains uncertain,
although it is known that he
favors a return to the wooden
stick. "I liked nothing better in
the game than having all those
guts on the field," explained the
ex-lax standout, who was noted
for spilling a few guts of his own
during his five year career.

Scott Sez
"I'd rather not say what
Action will be doing with the
team this spring," said Coach
Scott. "After all, I don't want
anything to appear in print that
the other coaches could ram back
down out throats." he finished,
declining further comment.

However, the News-Letter has
discovered these facts about the
new assistant:
—He wants to die when he's
forty
—He sliced his wrists to prove
his toughness
—His hobby is dangling off the
roof of the Athletic Center
—He enjoys pain
"I rather like the guy," said
Sports Information Director
Scott Starks, who is known to be
a little warped himself. "He's
kind of stupid, bui at least he
doesn't eat roaChes," Starks
added.
Jackson denied this rumor
vociferously.
"I have so eaten roaches,"
asserted Seymor. "In fact, during
the summer I rent myself out to
an exterminator."

Pictured above is D. Victor Krunch, winner of the 1973 26th
Annual Ffilbert Ffonzark Memorial Nutritionless Cereal Eating
Contest. This contest, held every year for the benefit ofstarving boa
constrictors in the Great Pikesville Area, took place at Reisterstown
Road Giant last Saturday. Krunch, a Hopkins student, ate 46,000
boxes of Quisp in 92 hours. If he is unrecognizable to fellow
Floppies, his moustache grew in during the contest. The
'Eat-'Em-Up' grossed $10,000,000 due to the high number of
goon-women in attendance.
